page.title: 19Ecology Newton/Linton
page.content: The ecology is typical of rural lowland.Trees,including sycamore,ash, oak and chestnut are scattered over the area,once covered by a Royal Forest.Many hedges have been pulled out and those remaining, hawthorn and blackthorn,are slashed well back,so destroying the habitat of wild life. Modern methods of farming have killed many wild flowers but bluebells, primroses and Himalayan balsalm remain and wild flowers grow by the roadside. Resident birds include thrushes, blackbirds,tits,robins and finches, with swallows,martins,swifts and cuckoos being summer visitors. Fieldfares visit in winter.Flocks of rooks wheel over the fields and tits and finches are fascinating to watch. Cock pheasants roam ploughed fields. Rabbits and foxes are found and grey squirrels live in the deciduous trees.
